diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect multiple systems including the kidneys, blood, brain, and joints, causing inflammation and tissue damage in the affected parts.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints but can also cause systemic inflammation, potentially affecting organs such as the kidneys.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that primarily affects the body's moisture-producing glands, but can also have systemic manifestations including joint pain and kidney involvement.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder characterized by hypercoagulability and a risk of both arterial and venous thrombosis, which can affect various organs, including the brain (leading to delirium) and kidneys.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders characterized by inflammation of blood vessels, which can affect any organ system, potentially leading to nephritis, neurological manifestations, and joint pain.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.description: A disorder featuring a combination of symptoms of systemic lupus erythematosus, scleroderma, and polymyositis, including joint swelling, muscle weakness, and kidney dysfunction.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease characterized by the formation of granulomas in multiple organs, which can include the kidneys, causing nephritis, and joints, leading to arthropathy.

diagnoses.name: Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition usually triggered by an infection leading to kidney failure and hemolysis. Although it primarily affects the kidneys, it can have systemic implications.

diagnoses.name: Primary Biliary Cholangitis
diagnoses.description: A chronic disease that slowly destroys the bile ducts in the liver, associated with other autoimmune disorders, and potential overlapping autoimmune symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body, including the brain and the digestive system, which could indirectly relate to neuropsychiatric symptoms and systemic effects.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease, where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks its tissues, can manifest in multiple organ systems with symptoms like inflammation of lymph nodes (lymphadenopathy) and liver involvement with abnormal enzymes.

diagnoses.name: Sepsis
diagnoses.description: A potentially life-threatening condition caused by the body's response to an infection, can lead to organ dysfunction, including elevated liver enzymes and hyperthermia.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus/Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome can lead to generalized lymphadenopathy, liver enzyme abnormalities due to opportunistic infections or drug toxicity, and may contribute to miscarriage.

diagnoses.name: Hepatitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the liver, often caused by viral infections, can present with abnormal liver enzymes and enlarged lymph nodes as part of the body's immune response.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, this condition often presents with fever (hyperthermia), swollen lymph glands (lymphadenopathy), and liver involvement (abnormal liver enzymes).

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that begins in the lymphatic system, lymphoma can cause lymphadenopathy, abnormal liver enzymes due to liver involvement, and fever (hyperthermia).

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection that mainly affects the lungs but can also affect the lymphatic system (lymphadenitis), cause liver dysfunction (abnormal liver enzymes), and fever (hyperthermia).

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that can affect various parts of the body, including the lymph nodes (lymphadenopathy) and liver, potentially leading to abnormal liver enzymes.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune hepatitis
diagnoses.description: A chronic condition where the body's immune system attacks liver cells, leading to inflammation and abnormal liver enzymes; could be associated with other autoimmune diseases that affect lymph nodes.

diagnoses.name: Toxoplasmosis
diagnoses.description: A parasitic infection that can cause flu-like symptoms, swollen lymph glands (lymphadenopathy), and liver involvement (abnormal liver enzymes); it's especially concerning during pregnancy as it can lead to miscarriage.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Hypothyroidism secondary to treatments (e.g., radioactive iodine, thyroidectomy)
Bone Marrow Failure Syndromes (e.g., Aplastic Anemia)

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer originating from white blood cells called lymphocytes. It can cause lymphadenopathy, depression due to the impact of the disease, and eosinophilia can be observed due to the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells.

diagnoses.name: Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A diverse group of blood cancers that include any kind of lymphoma except Hodgkin's lymphomas. Symptoms can include lymphadenopathy, and secondary conditions may lead to depression, eosinophilia, and obstructive sleep apnea due to enlarged lymph nodes.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory lung disease that causes obstructed airflow from the lungs. It can cause fatigue and depression, and obstructive sleep apnea is a common comorbidity. Palpitations might occur as a symptom of heart stress or low oxygen levels.

diagnoses.name: Cardiac Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects various organs but can severely impact the heart, causing palpitations, and arrhythmias. It can also cause lymphadenopathy and has been associated with eosinophilia.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by extreme fatigue or tiredness that doesn't improve with rest. It can cause depression, palpitations, obstructive sleep apnea, and is sometimes associated with immune system abnormalities that could explain eosinophilia.

diagnoses.name: Atypical Depression
diagnoses.description: A subtype of major depression or dysthymia that involves temporary mood lifts in response to positive events. Patients may experience fatigue contributing to obstructive sleep apnea, and the stress of the condition can lead to palpitations.

diagnoses.name: Hyperthyroidism
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the thyroid gland produces too much of the hormone thyroxine. It can accelerate the body's metabolism significantly, causing unexpected weight loss, palpitations, and sometimes eosinophilia due to the autoimmune nature of diseases like Graves' disease.

diagnoses.name: Hypereosinophilic Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by a persistently high count of eosinophils in the blood for at least six months without any apparent cause. It can lead to lymphadenopathy, palpitations, depression, and various organ damages, including heart and lung involvement which may manifest as obstructive sleep apnea.

diagnoses.name: Sleep-Disordered Breathing
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders characterized by abnormal respiratory patterns or insufficient ventilation during sleep, including obstructive sleep apnea. It can cause daytime sleepiness that may contribute to depression, and palpitations upon awakening.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.description: A group of mental health disorders characterized by significant feelings of anxiety and fear. Anxiety can cause palpitations and contribute to episodes of depression. Anxiety-related stress can exacerbate conditions like obstructive sleep apnea.

diagnoses: Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)

diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones, potentially leading to symptoms like constipation, sensitivity to cold, and possibly enlarged lymph nodes due to immune response.
Chronic kidney disease can lead to a build-up of waste products in the body, causing symptoms such as constipation, and an increased risk of cardiovascular disease due to atherosclerosis.

A metabolic disorder that can result in systemic complications like atherosclerosis due to high blood sugar levels, as well as potentially contributing to constipation and immune system dysfunction, affecting lymph nodes.

An autoimmune disease that can cause widespread inflammation and tissue damage in affected organs - including the skin, heart (related to atherosclerosis), and lymphatic system, potentially leading to symptoms such as lymphadenitis and sensitivity.

An autoimmune disorder that often accompanies other immune system disorders like lupus or rheumatoid arthritis, potentially causing dryness that might be mistaken for coryza, along with widespread inflammation affecting various body systems.
An infection typically caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, leading to symptoms like swollen lymph nodes (lymphadenitis), fatigue, and sore throat, along with coryza-like symptoms.
An autoimmune disorder affecting the joints primarily but can also cause systemic symptoms including cardiovascular complications like atherosclerosis, as well as affecting the lymph nodes.

A rare autoimmune disease causing hardening and tightening of the skin and connective tissues, potentially impacting gastrointestinal motility (resulting in constipation) and vascular health, contributing to atherosclerosis.

Chronic condition where the heart does not pump blood as well as it should, which can be a complication of untreated or poorly managed atherosclerosis, and can indirectly contribute to systemic symptoms including lymphadenopathy.

A viral respiratory infection causing symptoms such as coryza, mild lymphadenopathy, and potentially exacerbating physical sensitivities, though it is less likely to be directly associated with atherosclerosis or significant constipation.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Leukopenia - secondary to viral infection or bone marrow disorder
Lymphadenopathy - secondary to infection, malignancy, or autoimmune disease
Chronic Kidney Disease – as it can contribute to electrolyte imbalances affecting leukocyte production
Diabetes Mellitus – particularly Type 2, as it is often associated with gastroparesis
Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) – given its potential to cause leukopenia and lymphadenopathy
Lymphoma – considering lymphadenopathy and leukopenia as symptoms
Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) – due to its association with leukopenia, lymphadenopathy, and potentially autoimmune-related gastroparesis

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: Chronic kidney disease can lead to a decreased ability to filter blood and remove waste from the body, which can cause symptoms such as fatigue, increased susceptibility to infections, and changes in urine output that could contribute to urinary tract infections.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: Diabetes can lead to a range of complications that may include urinary tract infections due to glucose in the urine, increased susceptibility to infections, hearing loss, and kidney damage that can manifest as menorrhagia due to hormonal imbalances.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: Iron deficiency anemia can cause menorrhagia and fatigue. It can also make individuals more prone to infections due to impairments in immune response.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: Hypothyroidism can lead to menorrhagia and fatigue. It's also associated with an increased risk of infections.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: PCOS can cause irregular menstrual cycles, which can sometimes manifest as menorrhagia. It can also contribute to fatigue and is often associated with insulin resistance, which can increase the risk of diabetes.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorders
diagnoses.description: Certain autoimmune disorders, such as lupus, can cause a wide range of symptoms including increased susceptibility to infections, urinary tract issues, and hearing loss due to involvement of the kidneys and auditory nerves.

diagnoses.name: Uterine Fibroids
diagnoses.description: Uterine fibroids can lead to menorrhagia. The fatigue could be a secondary symptom arising from the menorrhagia-induced anemia.

diagnoses.name: Von Willebrand Disease
diagnoses.description: This is a genetic disorder that affects blood clotting, leading to symptoms such as menorrhagia. It can also cause anemia, which might contribute to feelings of fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Chronic fatigue syndrome could explain the fatigue and possibly the increased susceptibility to infections. However, it wouldn't directly cause menorrhagia or a urinary tract infection.

diagnoses.name: Pelvic Inflammatory Disease
diagnoses.description: Pelvic inflammatory disease can cause menorrhagia and may also increase the risk of urinary tract infections. Fatigue can be a related symptom due to the body's effort to fight the infection.
Depressive Disorder
Endometriosis
Hypothyroidism
Hypoglycemia, not elsewhere classified
Bipolar Disorder
Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
Anxiety Disorder
Premenstrual Dysphoric Disorder (PMDD)
Fibromyalgia
Chronic Fatigue Syndrome

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.reasoning: Increased appetite and potential to affect vision, although it doesn't directly explain decreased immunoglobulins or interstitial cystitis.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.reasoning: Plethora is a classic symptom due to increased red blood cell mass.

diagnoses.name: Primary Immunodeficiency
diagnoses.reasoning: Could explain decreased immunoglobulins, leading to increased susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses.name: Hyperthyroidism
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause increased appetite and occasionally eye symptoms, though it doesn't directly explain decreased immunoglobulins or interstitial cystitis.

diagnoses.name: Cushing’s Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Increased appetite and the possibility of impacting immune function, but less directly associated with the other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia
diagnoses.reasoning: Can lead to plethora due to increased red cell production in response to hemolysis; some types are associated with decreased immunoglobulins.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Autoimmune disorder that could potentially explain decreased immunoglobulins and has been associated with interstitial cystitis.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.reasoning: Can lead to decreased immunoglobulins over time due to the impact on the immune system, might indirectly relate to some other symptoms due to secondary conditions.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Though a diagnosis of exclusion and not directly related to the specific symptoms listed, could feasibly encompass a wide range of symptoms including difficulty focusing and interstitial cystitis.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Myeloma
diagnoses.reasoning: Cancer of plasma cells which can lead to decreased immunoglobulins, secondary infections, and potentially other systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of your body. It's characterized by flares and remission and can affect joints, skin, kidneys, blood cells, brain, heart, and lungs.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. In addition to joint symptoms, rheumatoid arthritis can also affect skin, eyes, lungs, heart, and blood vessels.

diagnoses.name: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) Infection
diagnoses.description: A virus that attacks the body's immune system. If untreated, it can lead to the disease AIDS (acquired immunodeficiency syndrome). Symptoms can include swollen lymph nodes and an increase in white blood cell count.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that originates in the lymphatic system. It affects lymphocytes, a type of white blood cell that fights infection.

diagnoses.name: Syphilis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection usually spread by sexual contact. It starts as a painless sore and can spread to the lymph nodes. If left untreated, it can affect the heart, brain, and other organs.

diagnoses.name: Mononucleosis (Mono)
diagnoses.description: Often called 'mono' or 'the kissing disease,' it's an infection usually caused by the Epstein-Barr virus. Symptoms can include fatigue, fever, rash, and swollen lymph nodes.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect the connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues. Symptoms might include overly flexible joints and stretchy, fragile skin.

diagnoses.name: Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis
diagnoses.description: The most common type of arthritis in children under the age of 16. It can cause persistent joint pain, swelling, and stiffness. Some children may experience symptoms for only a few months, while others have symptoms for the rest of their lives.

diagnoses.name: Cat Scratch Disease
diagnoses.description: An infection caused by Bartonella henselae bacteria. It is most commonly contracted after being scratched or bitten by an infected cat. Symptoms may include swollen lymph nodes, fever, fatigue, and headache.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, but mostly the lungs and lymph glands. Characterized by the growth of tiny collections of inflammatory cells in different parts of the body.

diagnoses: Major Depressive Disorder with Anxious Distress

diagnoses.name: Endometriosis
diagnoses.description: A painful, chronic disease where tissue similar to the lining inside the uterus grows outside the uterus.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: A common type of anemia that occurs due to insufficient dietary intake and absorption of iron, or iron loss from bleeding which can originate from a range of sources, including heavy menstrual periods often associated with endometriosis.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by hormonal imbalance and metabolism problems that can affect overall health and appearance. It's associated with a multitude of symptoms, including menstrual irregularity, which can sometimes be confused with or contribute to endometriosis.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A central nervous system (neurological) disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition. The fatigue worsens with physical or mental activity but doesn't improve with rest.

diagnoses.name: Folliculitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the hair follicles, caused by a bacterial, viral, fungal, or parasitic infection.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease in which the body's immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue in many parts of the body. Symptoms vary between individuals and can be mild to severe.

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that affects the lymphatic system, which is part of the body's immune system. It's characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells.

diagnoses.name: Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of lymphoma, which is a cancer of the lymphatic system. It encompasses a large group of cancers that affect lymphocytes.

diagnoses.name: Cervical Cancer
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that occurs in the cells of the cervix — the lower part of the uterus that connects to the vagina. Certain strains of the human papillomavirus (HPV), a sexually transmitted infection, play a role in causing most cervical cancer.

diagnoses.name: Systemic mastocytosis
diagnoses.description: A disorder where mast cells are abnormally increased in multiple organs including the bone marrow. It can cause symptoms like skin lesions (urticaria pigmentosa), systemic symptoms due to mast cell mediators release, including basophilia and episodes resembling anaphylaxis.

diagnoses.name: Chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML)
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that starts in the blood-forming cells of the bone marrow and invades the blood. It can lead to an increased number of basophils and other abnormal blood findings.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic condition characterized by recurrent episodes of severe swelling (angioedema). The swelling can occur in various parts of the body, including the extremities, face, gastrointestinal tract, and airway.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos syndrome
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues. Its vascular type might explain the presence of angioedema and specific forms of angioma.

diagnoses.name: Hypereosinophilic syndrome
diagnoses.description: A group of rare blood disorders characterized by the overproduction of eosinophils, a type of white blood cell. While not directly linked to basophilia, it can cause angioedema and might be associated with an increased risk of heart-related issues similar to postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Capillary malformation-arteriovenous malformation syndrome
diagnoses.description: This genetic disorder can cause multiple small angiomata (capillary malformations) on the skin and may result in arteriovenous malformations which can affect many organ systems.

diagnoses.name: Lymphatic malformations
diagnoses.description: A condition of the lymphatic system that can lead to localized angiomata. It is a congenital condition but can manifest or worsen in adulthood.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia vera
diagnoses.description: A blood cancer characterized by the overproduction of red blood cells. It can also lead to an increased production of basophils and cause a plethora of symptoms, including itching, which might exacerbate conditions like periodontal disease due to skin scratching.

diagnoses.name: Carney complex
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by increased risk of several types of tumors, skin abnormalities such as myxomas (a type of benign tumor that could resemble angiomata), and endocrine problems. It might also indirectly affect symptoms aligned with postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Multiple myeloma
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that affects plasma cells. It can cause a wide range of problems, including bone pain and damage, anemia, elevated calcium levels, and kidney failure. While it’s not directly connected to the provided symptoms, the systemic impact of this disease could contribute indirectly to their manifestation.

diagnoses: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (Secondary to a Chronic Condition)

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: A chronic digestive disease where stomach acid or bile irritates the food pipe lining.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Musculoskeletal Back Pain
diagnoses.description: A condition causing prolonged pain from muscles, joints, or bones in the back.

diagnoses.name: Human Papillomavirus (HPV) Infections
diagnoses.description: A viral infection that can cause warts on different parts of the body, including the genital area.

diagnoses.name: Oral Ulcers
diagnoses.description: Open sores or lesions in the mouth, which can cause oral pain.

diagnoses.name: Reactive Lymphadenopathy
diagnoses.description: Lymph node enlargement due to infection, autoimmune disease, or malignancy.

diagnoses.name: Osteoarthritis
diagnoses.description: A degenerative joint disease that can affect the lower back, causing pain and stiffness.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: A viral infection causing fever, sore throat, swollen lymph glands, and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Dental Abscess
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection at the root of a tooth or in the gums that can cause severe oral pain and swelling.

diagnoses.name: Esophagitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the esophagus, which can be a complication of GERD, causing pain and difficulty swallowing.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition that causes pain all over the body, which could contribute to chronic back pain.

diagnoses.name: Graves' Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that leads to overactivity of the thyroid gland (hyperthyroidism). It can cause symptoms like difficulty focusing vision, flushing, goiter, and in some cases, can affect digestion.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and damage to various body parts including joints, skin, kidneys, blood cells, brain, heart, and lungs. Symptoms can include flushing, difficulty focusing, and lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, but mostly the lungs and lymph glands. In some cases, it can affect the eyes (leading to vision problems), skin (flushing), and cause lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Neuroendocrine Tumor
diagnoses.description: A type of tumor that can produce excessive amounts of hormones, leading to symptoms such as flushing, difficulty focusing vision, and in some cases, gastrointestinal issues mirroring those of gastroparesis.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Gastroparesis
diagnoses.description: A condition that affects the stomach muscles and prevents proper stomach emptying, often associated with diabetes. It could potentially correlate with other systemic symptoms if diabetes is poorly managed.

diagnoses.name: Carcinoid Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition that occurs in patients with carcinoid tumors, leading to excessive production of serotonin and other chemicals that can cause flushing, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and in rare cases, effects on vision.

diagnoses.name: Pheochromocytoma
diagnoses.description: A rare tumor of adrenal gland tissue. It results in the production of excess hormones, leading to symptoms like flushing, high blood pressure, palpitations, and possibly effects on vision.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 1 (MEN1)
diagnoses.description: A hereditary condition that can lead to overactivity of the parathyroid, pancreas, and pituitary glands, causing a variety of symptoms including stomach ulcers, hypercalcemia, and possibly gastroparesis and hyperthyroidism.

diagnoses.name: Mast cell activation syndrome (MCAS)
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by excessive release of mast cell mediators. Symptoms can include flushing, abdominal pain mimicking gastroparesis, difficulty focusing, and lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Polyglandular Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare condition involving multiple endocrine organ disorders, it can lead to hyperthyroidism, adrenal insufficiency, and diabetes. It may manifest symptoms like gastroparesis due to autonomic neuropathy in diabetes.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition where the kidneys don't work as well as they should. It can cause a wide range of symptoms such as fatigue, swollen ankles, feet or hands (due to water retention), and shortness of breath.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Sclerosis (Scleroderma)
diagnoses.description: A rare, chronic disease of the connective tissue that causes skin thickening and hardening, joint pain, digestive problems, and in some cases, vascular problems like telangiectasias.

diagnoses.name: Pulmonary Hypertension
diagnoses.description: A type of high blood pressure that affects the arteries in the lungs and the right side of your heart. It can cause symptoms such as shortness of breath, fatigue, and chest pain. Patients with chronic kidney disease are at increased risk.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory lung disease that causes obstructed airflow from the lungs. Symptoms include breathing difficulty, cough, mucus (sputum) production, and wheezing. Chronic cough is a common symptom.

diagnoses.name: Sjogren’s Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands that make tears and saliva. It can also affect other parts of the body, including the kidneys and lungs, and may cause skin vasculature changes like telangiectasias.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia (HHT)
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that leads to abnormal blood vessel formation in the skin, mucous membranes, and often in organs such as the lungs, liver, and brain. It is characterized by frequent nosebleeds, telangiectasias, and organ arteriovenous malformations.

diagnoses.name: Vulvodynia
diagnoses.description: Chronic pain or discomfort around the opening of the vagina (vulva) for which there’s no identifiable cause and which lasts at least three months. It's a specific condition on its own, often associated with chronic pain syndromes.

diagnoses.name: Alzheimer’s Disease
diagnoses.description: The most common cause of progressive memory loss, Alzheimer’s disease is a degenerative brain disease that leads to a continuous decline in thinking, behavioral, and social skills.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition in which you lack enough healthy red blood cells to carry adequate oxygen to your body's tissues. It can cause fatigue and weakness, which may be related to chronic kidney disease.

diagnoses.name: Atypical Depression
diagnoses.description: A subtype of major depression or dysthymic disorder that involves several specific symptoms, including increased appetite or weight gain, sleepiness or excessive sleep, marked fatigue or weakness, moods that are strongly reactive to environmental circumstances, and feeling extremely sensitive to rejection. While not directly related to the listed symptoms, individuals with chronic illness may experience atypical depression.

diagnoses.name: Acute allergic reactions
diagnoses.description: Could manifest as angioedema and potentially exacerbate thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses.name: Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP)
diagnoses.description: Autoimmune disorder that leads to low platelet counts, which could indirectly contribute to thromboembolic disease.

diagnoses.name: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A systemic autoimmune disease that can cause thrombocytopenia, increase the risk of thromboembolic disease, and present with oral ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that increases the risk of thromboembolic events and can be associated with thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses.name: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Can cause increased appetite (due to corticosteroid treatment), angioedema, thrombocytopenia, and vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary angioedema
diagnoses.description: A genetic condition leading to episodes of severe swelling (angioedema). Though not directly linked with thrombocytopenia, it could complicate the medical picture.

diagnoses.name: Hypereosinophilic syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by high eosinophil counts that can lead to angioedema, thromboembolic events, and possibly an increase in appetite due to corticosteroid treatment.

diagnoses.name: Chronic myeloid leukemia (CML)
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that can present with elevated blood counts leading to an increased risk of thromboembolic events and might indirectly cause thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses.name: Gastric disorders
diagnoses.description: Includes conditions such as gastritis or peptic ulcers, which can lead to oral pain and vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Paraneoplastic syndromes
diagnoses.description: A group of symptoms that occur alongside cancer and can include increased appetite, angioedema, and thromboembolic disease due to hypercoagulability.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: Iron deficiency anemia can result from blood loss such as that associated with heavy periods (menorrhagia). Symptoms can include fatigue, which might contribute to perceptions of hyperactivity as the body attempts to compensate, and, in severe cases, might exacerbate conditions affecting hearing.

diagnoses.name: Von Willebrand Disease
diagnoses.description: A bleeding disorder that can lead to excessive bleeding such as menorrhagia. Although less directly related, it could contribute to anemia due to blood loss and might have peripheral implications for the other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)
diagnoses.description: Predominantly characterized by hyperactivity, ADHD can coexist with conditions or scenarios that provoke other presenting symptoms, though the direct link to menorrhagia, anemia, or hearing loss is less evident.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Disorders
diagnoses.description: Hyperthyroidism can manifest with symptoms of hyperactivity. Furthermore, thyroid disorders can indirectly affect menstrual cycle regulation, potentially leading to menorrhagia, and can be a rare cause of anemia.

diagnoses.name: Uterine Fibroids
diagnoses.description: Noncancerous growths in the uterus can cause menorrhagia and subsequently lead to anemia due to heavy and prolonged periods. While they do not directly cause hyperactivity or hearing loss, the symptoms of anemia might impact overall well-being.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Sinusitis
diagnoses.description: Chronic inflammation of the sinuses can lead to post-nasal drip. Although less commonly linked with the full spectrum of symptoms listed, complications or associated conditions could account for a broader symptom profile.

diagnoses.name: Idiopathic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder leading to low platelet counts, which can cause heavy menstrual periods (menorrhagia) and lead to anemia. The connection to hyperactivity or hearing loss is not direct but could relate to the overall health impacts of the condition.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear leading to episodes of vertigo and hearing loss. While the primary symptoms focus on balance and auditory challenges, the distress and impact on well-being could interact with other symptoms or conditions in complex ways.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder causing prolonged or infrequent menstrual periods or excess androgen levels. PCOS can lead to menorrhagia and has been associated with insulin resistance, which may indirectly influence energy levels and perceived hyperactivity.

diagnoses.The Diagnostic Value of Combining Sympto: In clinical practice, the combination of seemingly disparate symptoms such as hyperactivity, menorrhagia, anemia, hearing loss, and post-nasal drip requires a holistic assessment. While each of the aforementioned diagnoses could account for a portion of the symptom complex, a thorough diagnostic evaluation is essential. Intersectional symptomatology necessitates considering primary disorders alongside possible secondary effects, comorbidities, or syndromic associations.

diagnoses.explanation: An autoimmune disorder that often presents with dry eyes and can also cause leukoplakia due to mouth dryness. While it mainly affects moisture-producing glands, associated neurological problems can potentially lead to memory issues.

Various autoimmune conditions can lead to symptoms like dry eyes, hearing loss through autoimmune inner ear disease, and can indirectly cause memory problems due to systemic effects. Angioedema could be a rare manifestation or related to treatment complications.

diagnoses.diagnosis: Age-Related Hearing Loss and Cognitive Decline
diagnoses.explanation: Aging can lead to hearing loss and memory problems. Dry eyes are also more common in older adults. Angioedema and leukoplakia might result from other age-related conditions or treatments.
Certain medications can cause dry eyes, hearing loss, memory issues, leukoplakia (as a rare side effect), and angioedema (as an allergic reaction).

Though less common, some types of lymphoma can present with symptoms like dry eyes (secondary Sjögren's), leukoplakia due to immunocompromise, hearing loss, memory issues related to CNS involvement, and angioedema due to immune dysregulation.

Can lead to dry eyes and memory problems. Hearing loss is a less common symptom but has been reported. Leukoplakia and angioedema might be indirect manifestations or associated with this condition's complex metabolic effects.

HIV can cause leukoplakia and memory problems (due to HIV-associated neurocognitive disorders). Dry eyes could occur due to secondary Sjögren's syndrome or other autoimmune conditions. Hearing loss and angioedema are less commonly associated but potential manifestations.

Can lead to memory problems and has been associated with leukoplakia. Rarely, it might contribute to hearing loss. Angioedema and dry eyes are not directly caused by B12 deficiency but can be related to overall health status.
A rare condition that can present with varied symptoms including dry eyes, hearing loss, memory problems, and angioedema due to the deposition of amyloid protein in tissues.

Though not a direct cause of all symptoms, MS can lead to memory problems due to brain lesions, dry eyes as part of autoimmune dysfunction. Hearing loss is rare but has been reported. Angioedema could theoretically be linked to treatment side effects or overlapping autoimmune conditions.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth. It can lead to difficulty focusing vision due to the lack of tear production, and systemic features can mimic or cause interstitial cystitis. Weight loss and glycemic lability can also be associated due to the systemic nature of the disease and its potential impact on the pancreas.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A metabolic disorder characterized by high blood sugar levels over a prolonged period. Weight loss and glycemic lability are hallmark symptoms. Long-term complications can lead to various conditions including dry eyes from diabetic autonomic neuropathy.

diagnoses.name: Hyperthyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland is overactive and produces excessive amounts of thyroid hormones. Symptoms can include weight loss and eye symptoms such as dryness and focus issues due to the impact on ocular muscles and tear production. Interstitial cystitis symptoms may also be indirectly related through autoimmune mechanisms.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder characterized by chronic inflammation of joints, but it can also affect the eyes, causing dryness and difficulty focusing. Systemic manifestations can potentially include conditions with symptoms similar to interstitial cystitis. Weight loss can occur as a general symptom of chronic illness.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A systemic autoimmune disease that can affect many different body systems, including the kidneys, which could relate to interstitial cystitis-like symptoms, and the eyes, causing dryness and visual issues. Weight loss and glycemic lability can also be features due to the systemic nature of lupus.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: A virus affecting the immune system, leading to various systemic symptoms depending on the stage of infection. Dry eyes and weight loss are common in advanced stages. While interstitial cystitis is not a direct symptom, various urinary tract issues can occur due to the compromised immune system.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, primarily the lungs and lymph glands. Eye symptoms including dryness and visual changes, and systemic symptoms that might mimic interstitial cystitis can occur. Weight loss and systemic symptoms can also be present.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. Symptoms can include vision problems and bladder dysfunction, which might present similarly to interstitial cystitis. Weight loss and other systemic symptoms might occur in various stages of the disease.

diagnoses.name: Primary Biliary Cholangitis
diagnoses.description: A chronic disease that slowly destroys the bile ducts in the liver. Associated sicca syndrome (including dry eyes) may produce symptoms of difficulty in focusing vision, and systemic features can lead to weight loss and potentially glycemic lability due to liver dysfunction.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition. Dry eyes and difficulty focusing vision can be reported by patients, and weight loss might occur. Glycemic lability is not a hallmark feature but might be present due to associated metabolic changes.
Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: This is an autoimmune disease that attacks the glands that produce tears and saliva, leading to dry eyes, and can also affect other organs, potentially leading to gastroparesis and malabsorption.

diagnoses.description: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.rationale: Lupus is a systemic autoimmune disease that can cause a wide range of symptoms, including gastrointestinal issues like gastroparesis, malabsorption, skin and joint problems, as well as hematologic disorders like leukocytosis. Dysmenorrhea and dry eyes can also be symptoms.

diagnoses.description: Scleroderma
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease leads to hardening and tightening of the skin and connective tissues. It can also affect internal organs, causing symptoms such as gastroparesis and malabsorption. Scleroderma might also contribute to dysmenorrhea due to pelvic involvement and can cause dry eyes.

diagnoses.description: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Though primarily known as a joint disease, it can have systemic effects including Sjögren's syndrome (causing dry eyes), and potentially affect the gastrointestinal system, leading to gastroparesis. It can indirectly be associated with leukocytosis due to inflammation.

diagnoses.description: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.rationale: Diabetes, especially when poorly controlled, can lead to a complication known as diabetic gastroparesis. It can also cause malabsorption issues and contribute to leukocytosis due to infection risk. Dysmenorrhea and dry eyes are also possible complications.

diagnoses.description: Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: This group of disorders affect connective tissues and can lead to a wide variety of symptoms, including gastrointestinal issues like gastroparesis and malabsorption. While not directly causing leukocytosis, associated infections or complications could. Dysmenorrhea is common due to joint and connective tissue involvement.

diagnoses.description: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disorder is triggered by ingestion of gluten and primarily affects the small intestine leading to malabsorption. It can cause systemic issues including those affecting the gastrointestinal system (like gastroparesis), and potentially contribute to dysmenorrhea and dry eyes due to nutrient deficiencies.

diagnoses.description: Inflammatory Bowel Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This encompasses conditions like Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis, which can cause malabsorption, and in severe cases, gastroparesis due to intestinal inflammation and obstruction. Leukocytosis is common due to inflammation.

diagnoses.description: Gastrointestinal Lymphoma
diagnoses.rationale: A type of cancer that occurs in the gastrointestinal tract, which can cause malabsorption, gastroparesis due to tumor growth obstructing gastrointestinal movement, and leukocytosis as a result of the body's response to cancer.

diagnoses.description: Amyloidosis
diagnoses.rationale: This is a rare disease that occurs when an abnormal protein, amyloid, builds up in organs and tissues, leading to dysfunction. It can cause gastroparesis by affecting the gastrointestinal system, malabsorption, and potentially leukocytosis if the kidney or other organs are involved.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease, where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks its own tissues, affecting the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs. It can cause a wide range of symptoms, including rash, arthritis, and kidney problems.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body. Symptoms can include mouth sores, genital sores, eye inflammation, and skin rashes and lesions.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that begins in the lymphatic system, which is part of the body's germ-fighting network. It can cause lymphadenopathy, pruritus, and can sometimes be associated with monocytosis.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: A chronic, potentially life-threatening condition caused by the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). It can lead to weakened immune system and various infections or HIV-related cancers. Symptoms can include lymphadenopathy and various skin conditions.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease affecting multiple organs in the body, but mostly the lungs and lymph glands. Characterized by the formation of granulomas, it can cause lymphadenopathy and skin rashes.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It primarily affects the lungs but can also affect lymph nodes, causing lymphadenitis, and can have systemic effects like night sweats and weight loss.

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of lymphoma, which is a cancer of the lymphatic system. It can cause symptoms like swollen lymph nodes, night sweats, weight loss, and itching.

diagnoses.name: Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A group of blood cancers that includes all types of lymphoma except Hodgkin's lymphomas. Symptoms include enlarged lymph nodes, fever, night sweats, weight loss, and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Syphilis
diagnoses.description: A sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. It can cause a wide range of symptoms in its various stages, including rashes and lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels. It can cause various symptoms depending on which vessels and organs are affected. Symptoms might include rashes, headaches, and muscle pain.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder where the ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine, potentially causing malabsorption, bone pain, and other systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder marked by sudden recurrent episodes of sensory disturbance, loss of consciousness, or convulsions, associated with abnormal electrical activity in the brain.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin D Deficiency
diagnoses.description: A condition that occurs when the level of vitamin D in your body is too low, leading to bone pain and muscle weakness.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves, which can lead to a wide range of symptoms including problems with vision, arm or leg movement, sensation, or balance.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease in which the body's immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue in many parts of the body, leading to widespread inflammation and tissue damage in the affected organs.

diagnoses.name: Inflammatory Bowel Disease
diagnoses.description: An umbrella term used to describe disorders that involve chronic inflammation of your digestive tract. Types include Ulcerative Colitis and Crohn’s Disease.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory and mood issues.

diagnoses.name: Hypoparathyroidism
diagnoses.description: A rare condition in which the body produces an abnormally low amount of parathyroid hormone, leading to low levels of calcium in the blood, which can cause bone pain.

diagnoses.name: Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis
diagnoses.description: A disease of the bile ducts that causes inflammation and subsequent obstruction of bile ducts both inside and outside of the liver.

diagnoses.name: Crohn’s Disease
diagnoses.description: A type of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that may affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract from mouth to anus, causing a wide range of symptoms.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
diagnoses: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) despite normal pulmonary function tests
Autoimmune diseases (e.g., Rheumatoid arthritis, Systemic lupus erythematosus)
Chronic infections (e.g., Human papillomavirus infection for warts)
Liver diseases (e.g., Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease, Hepatitis)

Endocrine disorders (e.g., Thyroid diseases causing palpitations)

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones, potentially leading to symptoms like hypothermia and attention deficit.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues. It can lead to fibrosis and onychodystrophy.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Chemical Sensitivity
diagnoses.description: A chronic condition characterized by severe sensitivity or allergy-like reactions to many different kinds of pollutants including solvents, VOCs (volatile organic compounds), perfumes, petrol, diesel, smoke, 'chemicals' in general and often encompasses problems with regard to pollen, house dust mites, and pet fur.

diagnoses.name: Psoriasis
diagnoses.description: A skin disease that causes red, itchy scaly patches, most commonly on the knees, elbows, trunk, and scalp. Psoriasis is a common cause of onychodystrophy.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Sclerosis (Scleroderma)
diagnoses.description: A chronic connective tissue disease generally classified as one of the autoimmune rheumatic diseases. Scleroderma can lead to skin fibrosis and can affect the body's response to temperature, possibly contributing to hypothermia.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, but mostly the lungs and lymph glands. In people with sarcoidosis, abnormal masses or nodules called granulomas, consisting of inflamed tissues, can form as lumps under the skin and in other organs, leading to fibrosis.

diagnoses.name: Peripheral Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A result of damage to your peripheral nerves, often causing weakness, numbness, and pain, usually in your hands and feet. It can also affect other areas and body functions including digestion, urination, and circulation, potentially contributing to hypothermia.

diagnoses.name: Raynaud's Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes some areas of your body — such as your fingers and toes — to feel numb and cold in response to cold temperatures or stress. Raynaud's disease could potentially exacerbate sensitivity to environmental factors.

diagnoses.name: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)
diagnoses.description: A brain disorder marked by an ongoing pattern of inattention and/or hyperactivity-impulsivity that interferes with functioning or development. Although it doesn't directly correlate with the other symptoms, attention deficit is a primary indicator.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorders
diagnoses.description: A condition arising from an abnormal immune response to a normal body part. Several autoimmune diseases can lead to the combination of symptoms listed, through various mechanisms including fibrosis, sensitivities to chemicals, and others.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Neurological autoimmune disorders (e.g., Multiple sclerosis, Autoimmune encephalitis)
Hashimoto's Thyroiditis with fluctuating thyroid function
Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes (vascular type for vascular anomalies)

diagnoses.name: Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA)
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by repetitive episodes of upper airway obstruction during sleep due to the relaxation of throat muscles.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.description: A mood disorder causing a persistent feeling of sadness and loss of interest. It affects how the person feels, thinks and behaves.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.description: A group of mental health disorders characterized by significant feelings of anxiety and fear.

diagnoses.name: Heart Arrhythmias
diagnoses.description: Improper beating of the heart, whether irregular, too fast, or too slow. It can cause palpitations.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions that affect the thyroid gland, which can impact energy levels, mood, and weight. May relate to palpitations and depression.

diagnoses.name: Bacterial Vaginosis
diagnoses.description: A type of vaginal inflammation caused by the overgrowth of bacteria naturally found in the vagina, which disrupts the natural balance.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition in which blood lacks adequate healthy red blood cells, leading to fatigue and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Reactions
diagnoses.description: An immune system reaction to a particular substance (allergen). Symptoms can include hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: A digestive disease in which stomach acid or bile irritates the food pipe lining. It can be linked to sleep disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder common among women of reproductive age. Women with PCOS may have infrequent or prolonged menstrual periods or excess male hormone (androgen) levels.

diagnoses: Secondary Immunodeficiency due to Corticosteroid Use

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of your body. It's characterized by acute and chronic inflammation of various tissues of the body.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth. It often accompanies other immune system disorders, such as rheumatoid arthritis and lupus.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: A tick-borne illness caused by the bacterium Borrelia burgdorferi. Symptoms can include fatigue, headache, fever, and skin rash called erythema migrans. If left untreated, infection can spread to joints, the heart, and the nervous system.

diagnoses.name: Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Often called mono, is an infectious illness that’s sometimes called 'the kissing disease.' It's transmitted through saliva. Symptoms include fatigue, fever, rash, and swollen glands.

diagnoses.name: Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A reaction similar to hives, but it affects deeper layers of your skin. It's often seen in areas with loose areas of tissue, especially the face and throat, and sometimes the limbs and genitals.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones. It can cause symptoms like fatigue, weight gain, and memory problems.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition. The fatigue worsens with physical or mental activity but doesn't improve with rest.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues. It amplifies painful sensations by affecting the way your brain processes pain signals.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. Symptoms include fatigue, difficulty walking, numbness or weakness in one or more limbs, and problems with vision.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Reaction
diagnoses.description: A reaction caused by the body's immune system to a substance that does not bother most other people. Substances that often cause reactions are pollen, animal dander, nuts, insects, medications, and foods.
