diagnoses.name: Viral gastroenteritis
diagnoses.description: An intestinal infection marked by watery diarrhea, abdominal cramps, nausea or vomiting, and sometimes fever.

diagnoses.name: Influenza
diagnoses.description: A viral infection that attacks your respiratory system — your nose, throat, and lungs. Influenza is commonly called the flu.

diagnoses.name: COVID-19
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus, leading to respiratory illness that can spread from person to person. Symptoms can range from mild to severe.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety disorders
diagnoses.description: A variety of disorders that cause fear, nervousness, apprehension, and worrying. These disorders can affect how we feel and behave, and they can manifest real physical symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Cardiac arrhythmia
diagnoses.description: A group of conditions in which the heartbeat is irregular, too fast, or too slow. A heart rate above 100 beats per minute (tachycardia) in adults is considered abnormal.

diagnoses.name: Dehydration
diagnoses.description: A harmful reduction in the amount of water in the body resulting from not drinking enough fluids, excessive sweating, diarrhea, or vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Allergic rhinitis
diagnoses.description: An allergic response causing itchy, watery eyes, sneezing, and other similar symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Asthma
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your airways narrow and swell and may produce extra mucus. This can make breathing difficult and trigger coughing, wheezing, and shortness of breath.

diagnoses.name: Orthostatic hypotension
diagnoses.description: A form of low blood pressure that happens when you stand up from sitting or lying down. Orthostatic hypotension can make you feel dizzy or lightheaded, and maybe even faint.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: A chronic digestive disease in which stomach acid or, occasionally, bile flows back into your food pipe (esophagus).

diagnoses: Migraine (some forms can induce sneezing and vomiting)
COVID-19 (considering the wide range of symptoms associated with the virus)
Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) with Kidney Involvement

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by visual disturbances (scotoma), sensitivity to sound (phonophobia), and sometimes weakness. Patients often experience a pre-headache phase known as an aura, which can include visual, sensory, or speech disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Migraine without Aura
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition characterized by intense, debilitating headaches, often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound (phonophobia), but not preceded by aura.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear that causes episodes of vertigo, hearing loss, tinnitus (ringing in the ear), and a feeling of fullness in the ear. It can lead to long-term hearing loss and persistent tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Idiopathic Intracranial Hypertension
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by increased pressure around the brain without a detectable cause, leading to symptoms like headache, vision problems, and occasionally tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Abnormal growth of cells within the brain that can cause a variety of symptoms depending on its location, including headache, weakness, sensory changes, and sometimes tinnitus or auditory disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease affecting the brain and spinal cord. It can cause a wide range of symptoms, including weakness, coordination and balance issues, and in some cases, auditory symptoms like tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Vestibular Migraine
diagnoses.description: A variant of migraine where the primary symptom is vertigo. Patients may also experience migraine-related symptoms such as photophobia, phonophobia, and visual disturbances including scotoma.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA is a temporary blockage of blood flow to the brain, causing short-term symptoms similar to a stroke, such as weakness and headache. Tinnitus and visual disturbances can also occur.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by a lack of healthy red blood cells, which can lead to generalized weakness, fatigue, and sometimes headache. Severe or chronic cases can also cause tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Temporal Arteritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease of blood vessels, most often the temporal arteries, causing headache, scalp tenderness, jaw pain during chewing, and occasionally symptoms like vision disturbances and tinnitus.

diagnoses: Migraine (particularly basilar or with brainstem aura)

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Strokes may cause symptoms such as paralysis, speech difficulties, and time-dependent loss of muscle movement.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: Migraines are a neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms. It’s frequently characterized by intense, debilitating headaches. Symptoms may include nausea, vomiting, difficulty speaking, numbness or tingling, and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A brain tumor occurs when abnormal cells form within the brain. There are two main types of tumors: malignant or cancerous tumors and benign tumors. Brain tumors can cause headaches, seizures, problems with vision, vomiting, and mental changes.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: Multiple Sclerosis (MS) is a potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). MS can cause a wide range of symptoms, including muscle weakness, difficulty with coordination and balance, speech problems, and hearing loss.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic Neuroma
diagnoses.description: An acoustic neuroma is a noncancerous tumor that develops on the eighth cranial nerve, which leads from your inner ear to your brain. The pressure from the tumor can cause hearing loss, ringing in your ear, and unsteadiness.

diagnoses.name: Temporal Arteritis
diagnoses.description: Temporal arteritis is an inflammation of the blood vessels, called arteries, in and around your scalp. This condition can cause headaches, jaw pain, vision problems, and even hearing loss.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a ‘mini-stroke,’ transient ischemic attacks are brief, and symptoms are similar to those of a stroke but usually last only a few minutes and cause no permanent damage. They can produce symptoms like aphasia, numbness, weakness, and sudden headache.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Meningitis is an inflammation of the fluid and membranes (meninges) surrounding your brain and spinal cord. The swelling from meningitis typically triggers symptoms such as headache, fever, and a stiff neck.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: Encephalitis is inflammation of the brain. There are several causes, including viral infection. Symptoms include headache, fever, confusion, a stiff neck, and back pain. Hearing problems and speech difficulties can also occur.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: Lyme disease is a bacterial infection you can get from the bite of an infected deer tick. The first sign is usually a circular rash. As the infection spreads, it can cause a variety of symptoms, including numbness, weakness, facial palsy, and headaches.

diagnoses: Poisoning (e.g., carbon monoxide poisoning, heavy metal poisoning)

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by visual disturbances and other aura symptoms. Photophobia and phonophobia are common, and some individuals may experience transient numbness or weakness.

diagnoses.name: Migraine without Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache marked by intense, debilitating pain often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound, without preceding aura.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear causing vertigo, hearing loss, and tinnitus. Fullness in the ear or transient hearing loss and occasional numbness can be symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease affecting the central nervous system, leading to varied neurological symptoms including numbness, weakness, and in some cases, sensory hypersensitivities.

diagnoses.name: Vestibular Neuronitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the vestibular nerve, might cause hearing loss and balance problems along with sensitivity to sound; however, photophobia is not a primary symptom.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic Neuroma
diagnoses.description: A benign tumor on the nerve that connects the ear to the brain, leading to hearing loss, tinnitus, and sometimes balance issues or facial numbness.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Abnormal cell growth in the brain, symptoms depend on location but can include headaches, seizures, sensory changes, and cognitive or physical weakness.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often referred to as a mini-stroke, causing temporary periods of symptoms similar to those of a stroke, such as weakness and numbness, possibly affecting vision and causing photophobia.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, potentially causing fever, headache, stiff neck, photophobia, and phonophobia.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death, causing side-specific weakness, numbness, potential vision changes, and cognitive symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by visual disturbances and other aura symptoms before the head pain begins.

diagnoses.name: Migraine without Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that occurs without the specific warning signals known as aura.

diagnoses.name: Cluster Headaches
diagnoses.description: Severely painful headaches that occur in clusters, marked by one-sided pain.

diagnoses.name: Tension-Type Headaches
diagnoses.description: A common type of headache characterized by a dull, aching pain and tightness in the forehead or back of the neck.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease of the central nervous system that can cause visual disturbances (including scotoma), parasthesia, and other neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, it can lead to temporary neurological symptoms such as headache, aphasia, and sensory disturbances including parasthesia.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells within the brain or the skull vault, which can cause a variety of symptoms depending on its location, including headache, sensory loss, and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Optic Neuritis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the optic nerve that can cause vision loss and scotoma, often associated with multiple sclerosis.

diagnoses.name: Medication Overuse Headaches
diagnoses.description: Headaches arising from the overuse of medication, particularly for headache treatment. It is sometimes accompanied by other side effects such as phonophobia.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.description: Though not directly causing the other symptoms, anxiety can exacerbate or simulate symptoms like headache, parasthesia, and phonophobia.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disorder affecting movement, sensensation, and bodily functions.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that involves visual disturbances and other neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, it’s a brief period of symptoms similar to those you'd have in a stroke.

diagnoses.name: Peripheral Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A result of damage to your peripheral nerves, often causes weakness, numbness, and pain, usually in your hands and feet.

diagnoses.name: Vertebrobasilar Insufficiency
diagnoses.description: A condition arising from restricted blood flow to the back of the brain, causing symptoms like dizziness, double vision, or imbalance.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Any intracranial tumor caused by abnormal and uncontrolled cell division, either in the brain itself, the cranial nerves, the brain envelopes, skull, pituitary and pineal gland.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves, causing symptoms ranging from weakness and tingling to paralysis.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the brain and spinal cord membranes, typically caused by an infection.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A type of nerve damage that can occur with diabetes, affecting the legs and feet.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. Symptoms can include aphasia, weakness, and sometimes scintillation or visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a brief period of symptoms similar to those in a stroke. A TIA doesn’t cause permanent damage. It can produce symptoms like weakness, aphasia, and parasthesia.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: Multiple sclerosis is a disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). The immune system attacks the protective sheath (myelin) that covers nerve fibers, causing communication problems between your brain and the rest of your body. Symptoms can include weakness, parasthesia, and in some cases, scintillation.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: Migraine with aura is a type of migraine that involves neurological disturbances such as visual disturbances or scintillation, sensory changes (including parasthesia), and sometimes speech disturbances like aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A brain tumor can be either non-cancerous (benign) or cancerous (malignant), depending on its nature. Symptoms can include aphasia, parasthesia, weakness, and scintillation due to pressure on certain parts of the brain.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: Epilepsy is a central nervous system (neurological) disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness. Specific types of epilepsy can cause sensory disturbances and aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Cerebral Aneurysm
diagnoses.description: A cerebral aneurysm is a weak or thin spot on a blood vessel in the brain that balloons or bulges out and can press on a nerve causing paralysis, weakness, aphasia, and other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: Lyme disease is a bacterial infection you get from the bite of an infected tick. When it spreads to the nervous system, it can lead to symptoms such as weakness, parasthesia, and in rare cases, neurological disorders including facial palsy and memory problems.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barré Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Guillain-Barré Syndrome is a rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves. Weakness and tingling in your extremities are usually the first symptoms. These sensations can quickly spread, eventually paralyzing your whole body.

diagnoses.name: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)
diagnoses.description: Also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, ALS is a progressive nervous system disease that affects nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord, causing loss of muscle control. Symptoms include weakness and as the disease progresses, it can lead to difficulties with speech (aphasia).

diagnoses: Neurodegenerative Disorders (e.g., Parkinson's Disease, Huntington's Disease)

diagnoses.name: Migraine with aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by recurrent attacks of moderate to severe pain. The aura may include visual disturbances such as scintillation, and sometimes sensory, motor, or speech/language symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear causing vertigo, hearing loss, and tinnitus. It may occasionally present with headache and a feeling of fullness in the ear.

diagnoses.name: Transient ischemic attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a 'mini-stroke,' a TIA is a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. It can include headache, weakness, and problems with vision such as scintillation.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death. It can present with sudden headache, weakness, blurred vision, and sometimes hearing loss or changes.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. It can cause a wide range of symptoms including visual disturbances, weakness, and headaches.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain. Depending on its location, it can cause headaches, vision problems, hearing loss, and weakness among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Vestibular Schwannoma (Acoustic Neuroma)
diagnoses.description: A benign tumor on the main nerve leading from the inner ear to the brain. Symptoms may include hearing loss, tinnitus, dizziness, balance problems, and headaches.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An infection of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord. Symptoms can include headache, weakness, fever, and in severe cases, hearing loss.

diagnoses.name: Temporal Arteritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of blood vessels, typically in the head. Symptoms can include severe headaches, jaw pain, vision problems, and sometimes symptoms affecting hearing.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Inner Ear Disease (AIED)
diagnoses.description: An immune system disease that attacks the inner ear, leading to a progressive loss of hearing and sometimes balance disorders. Headache and generalized weakness can also occur.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by recurrent attacks of moderate to severe pain. The aura involves visual disturbances and other neurological symptoms that appear before the head pain and usually last less than an hour.

diagnoses.name: Migraine without aura
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms but is primarily known for its severe, debilitating headaches. Symptoms can include nausea, phonophobia, and vomiting, but without the preceding aura.

diagnoses.name: Cluster headaches
diagnoses.description: Intensely painful headaches that occur in cycles or 'clusters.' They are marked by severe unilateral temple or periorbital pain, often accompanied by symptoms such as lacrimation, nasal congestion, and restlessness.

diagnoses.name: Tension-type headache
diagnoses.description: The most common type of primary headache, characterized by a dull, aching head pain and tightness or pressure across the forehead or on the sides and back of the head.

diagnoses.name: Brain tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain. Symptoms may include headaches, nausea, vomiting, vision problems, loss of sensation or movement in an arm or a leg, difficulty with balance, speech difficulties, confusion, or personality changes.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the membranes covering the brain and spinal cord. Symptoms can include severe headache, nausea, vomiting, fever, confusion, drowsiness, and sensitivity to light.

diagnoses.name: Subarachnoid hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: Bleeding in the space between the brain and the surrounding membrane (subarachnoid space). It's characterized by a sudden, severe headache, often described as the 'worst headache' ever experienced, followed by vomiting and sometimes loss of consciousness.

diagnoses.name: Idiopathic intracranial hypertension
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by high pressure in the fluid around the brain, presenting symptoms similar to those of a brain tumor without the presence of a tumor. Symptoms include chronic headache, nausea, vomiting, and sometimes momentary episodes of blurred vision.

diagnoses.name: Temporal arteritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels, called arteries, in and around the scalp. Symptoms of this condition may include severe headache, scalp tenderness, jaw pain, vision problems, and symptoms of polymyalgia rheumatica.

diagnoses.name: Preeclampsia
diagnoses.description: A condition in pregnancy characterized by high blood pressure and signs of damage to another organ system, most often the liver and kidneys. It's marked by headaches, visual disturbances, upper abdominal pain, and vomiting.

diagnoses: Lupus nephritis (specific for proteinuria in the context of lupus)
Chronic Kidney Disease (secondary to systemic disease)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can present with a wide range of symptoms, including skin manifestations (such as a rash), inflammation of the heart's covering (pericarditis), oral ulcers, and hemolytic anemia.

diagnoses.name: Behcet's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Behcet's disease is characterized by oral ulcers, genital ulcers, and various skin lesions, alongside more serious systemic symptoms such as vascular and neurological manifestations. It might also involve immune-mediated inflammatory processes leading to symptoms like those listed.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Though primarily known for joint inflammation, Rheumatoid Arthritis can also cause systemic issues including skin rashes, anemia, and, less commonly, pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: Sarcoidosis is characterized by the formation of granulomas in various organs. It can present with skin manifestations, pericarditis, and anemia due to systemic inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Pemphigus Vulgaris
diagnoses.rationale: Pemphigus Vulgaris often presents with oral ulcers, and can be associated with other systemic immunological disturbances that might lead to hemolytic anemia. Skin involvement typically includes blisters rather than a verrucous rash, but differential diagnosis should consider potential overlap of symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Ankylosing Spondylitis
diagnoses.rationale: While this is primarily a disease affecting the spine, Ankylosing Spondylitis can sometimes manifest with systemic features such as heart inflammation (pericarditis) and anemia.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: MCTD is an autoimmune disease that can present with features of several other conditions such as lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis, including skin rashes, hemolytic anemia, and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily a cancer of the lymphatic system, lymphoma can manifest with a broad set of symptoms including skin changes, hemolytic anemia, and more rarely, pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Psoriasis
diagnoses.rationale: Psoriasis, particularly when severe, can be associated with systemic complications. Though not typically associated with hemolytic anemia or pericarditis, it can lead to severe skin manifestations and, in the context of psoriatic arthritis, systemic inflammatory responses.

diagnoses.name: Infective Endocarditis
diagnoses.rationale: Though a less common manifestation, infective endocarditis can lead to dermatological manifestations (including Janeway lesions which are not verrucous but can be misidentified), as well as anemia of chronic disease and indirect signs of systemic involvement such as heart inflammation.

diagnoses: Hepatitis B or C with cryoglobulinemia
Sjögren's syndrome with renal and hematological manifestations
Schizophrenia (for psychosis with no clear autoimmune association)
HIV/AIDS (can present with lymphopenia and a broad spectrum of skin and psychiatric symptoms)
Viral Infections (e.g., Epstein-Barr virus, Parvovirus B19)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Lupus with Central Nervous System Involvement
HELLP Syndrome (Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, Low Platelet count)
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia and Thrombocytopenia)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Peripheral Neuropathy, Myopathy, Hoarseness, and Hearing Loss (PNHHL)
Viral Infection (e.g., Parvovirus B19, Epstein-Barr virus)
Viral Infections (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis, Epstein-Barr Virus)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can affect multiple systems including the nervous system (leading to delirium), the cardiovascular system (pericarditis), the kidneys (proteinuria), and the hematopoietic system (leukopenia), and can cause myelitis.

diagnoses.name: Viral infection
diagnoses.rationale: Certain viral infections can lead to a spectrum of symptoms including delirium (due to encephalitis), pericarditis, leukopenia, proteinuria (as a result of kidney involvement), and myelitis.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: MCTD features signs and symptoms of several connective tissue diseases including SLE, which could account for delirium, pericarditis, leukopenia, proteinuria, and myelitis.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Advanced or systemic manifestations of rheumatoid arthritis can affect various organs leading to complications like pericarditis, leukopenia due to medications or disease activity, proteinuria as part of renal involvement, and rare neurological manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: Though rare, sarcoidosis can present with nervous system involvement (neurosarcoidosis) that may manifest as delirium, carditis including pericarditis, renal dysfunction (proteinuria), and granulomatous inflammation affecting the spinal cord (myelitis). Leukopenia is less commonly associated but can occur.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This vasculitis can present with a wide range of symptoms due to inflammation of blood vessels anywhere in the body, including neurological symptoms (delirium), cardiovascular (pericarditis), renal (proteinuria), and spinal cord involvement (myelitis). Leukopenia is not typically a primary feature but could be seen in the context of systemic inflammation or treatments.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis (TB)
diagnoses.rationale: Extrapulmonary TB can cause widespread systemic symptoms including pericarditis and rarely, neurological manifestations (which could present as delirium), renal involvement (proteinuria), and spinal involvement (Pott's disease). Leukopenia could occur in the context of miliary TB or as a side effect of treatment.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Late stage Lyme disease can present with neurological involvement (neuroborreliosis), carditis including pericarditis, potential kidney involvement (proteinuria), and very rarely, spinal cord inflammation (myelitis). Leukopenia is not characteristic but could occur.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.rationale: HIV/AIDS can lead to a wide array of complications as it progresses, including neurological problems (HIV-associated neurocognitive disorders), cardiomyopathy or pericarditis, renal disease (HIV-associated nephropathy leading to proteinuria), and opportunistic infections or complications leading to myelitis. Leukopenia is common due to the virus's impact on the immune system.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.rationale: MS primarily involves the nervous system and can present with delirium due to acute relapses or complications. It typically does not directly cause pericarditis, leukopenia, or proteinuria, but its association with myelitis is fundamental. Presence of these additional symptoms would warrant investigation for overlapping systemic diseases or complications.

diagnoses: Hepatitis B or C with cryoglobulinemia

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.details: An autoimmune disease where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue. It can affect the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs, presenting with a wide range of symptoms including arthropathy, thrombocytopenia, and nonscarring alopecia.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.details: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. It can cause synovitis and arthropathy. While less common, it can lead to thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma
diagnoses.details: A group of autoimmune diseases that may result in changes to the skin, blood vessels, muscles, and internal organs. Symptoms can include telangiectasias and arthropathy.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.details: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and skin rash. Telangiectasias and nonscarring alopecia can be observed.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.details: A rare autoimmune disorder that exhibits features of SLE, scleroderma, and polymyositis, including arthropathy, thrombocytopenia, and telangiectasias.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome (APS)
diagnoses.details: An autoimmune disorder characterized by thrombosis and/or pregnancy-related complications along with the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies. Can lead to thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses.name: Undifferentiated Connective Tissue Disease (UCTD)
diagnoses.details: A disease that presents with symptoms seen in systemic autoimmune diseases like those mentioned above but does not fulfill the criteria for any of them specifically. Symptoms can evolve over time.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.details: An inflammatory form of arthritis associated with psoriasis, noted for potential skin issues and joint involvement. May present arthropathy and synovitis.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Arthritis
diagnoses.details: A form of arthritis associated with Systemic Lupus Erythematosus that primarily affects the joints. It is characterized by arthropathy and can co-occur with thrombocytopenia in the context of SLE.

diagnoses.name: Primary Immune Thrombocytopenia
diagnoses.details: A disorder that can lead to easy or excessive bruising and bleeding resulting from low levels of platelets. While it is primarily associated with thrombocytopenia, patients may have other autoimmune symptoms.

diagnoses: Rheumatoid arthritis with associated skin lesions
Hepatitis B or C with associated cryoglobulinemia
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)
Evans syndrome (Autoimmune hemolytic anemia with immune thrombocytopenia)
Chronic Viral Infections (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis C)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease characterized by inflammation of various parts of the body. It can manifest with skin conditions like panniculitis and nonscarring alopecia, renal involvement leading to proteinuria, and hematological abnormalities including thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses.name: Cryoglobulinemia
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by the presence of abnormal proteins (cryoglobulins) in the blood that precipitate out of the serum at low temperatures. This can lead to symptoms such as chilblains, skin ulcers, and kidney problems (proteinuria), along with possible thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash. Though panniculitis is rare, dermatomyositis can present with nonscarring alopecia, Gottron's papules might resemble chilblains, and there's a risk of thrombocytopenia and kidney involvement.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.description: MCTD features signs and symptoms of a combination of disorders — including systemic lupus erythematosus, scleroderma, and polymyositis. Patients may experience Raynaud’s phenomenon (related to chilblains), skin changes, alopecia, blood disorders such as thrombocytopenia, and kidney involvement.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout your body, including the skin. Behçet's disease might manifest with various skin lesions, and while not directly causing chilblains or specified as causing panniculitis, its diverse skin manifestations and potential for alopecia, thrombocytopenia, and kidney damage (proteinuria) merit its inclusion.

diagnoses.name: Churg-Strauss Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Also known as Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (EGPA), it's a disorder marked by inflammation of blood vessels. It can manifest with skin symptoms, renal involvement, and occasionally thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses.name: Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (HSP)
diagnoses.description: A form of vasculitis affecting the skin, gut, joints, and kidneys, leading to a purpuric rash, abdominal pain, arthritis, and renal involvement like proteinuria. Thrombocytopenia is uncommon but can occur.

diagnoses.name: Polyarteritis Nodosa (PAN)
diagnoses.description: A rare vasculitis that can affect nerves, skin, kidneys, and other organs. It can cause skin ulcers and nodules (which might involve panniculitis), renal issues (proteinuria), but alopecia and thrombocytopenia are less common.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma (Systemic Sclerosis)
diagnoses.description: A group of autoimmune diseases that may result in changes to the skin, blood vessels, muscles, and internal organs. Proteinuria can indicate renal involvement. Skin manifestations could resemble the listed symptoms, although direct associations with panniculitis and chilblain are rare.

diagnoses.name: Idiopathic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP)
diagnoses.description: A bleeding disorder in which the blood doesn't clot as it should due to a low number of platelets (thrombocytopenia). While primarily known for causing easy or excessive bruising and bleeding, it is less commonly associated with the other listed symptoms but is included due to the prominence of thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses: Infectious diseases (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect multiple systems including the skin, joints, kidneys, heart, and blood cells. It often presents with a variety of symptoms such as rash, arthritis, and fatigue. Leukopenia, hemolytic anemia, and pericarditis are also common findings.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints but can also cause systemic symptoms. While it's more known for its effects on the joints, it can also cause anemia and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder that may have features of lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis; it includes symptoms like swelling of hands, joint pain, muscle inflammation, and might manifest with hematological abnormalities including hemolytic anemia and leukopenia.

diagnoses.name: Evans Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder characterized by the combination of autoimmune hemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia or neutropenia, which can present alongside other autoimmune disorders.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma
diagnoses.description: An group of autoimmune diseases that cause the skin and connective tissues to harden. While primarily affecting the skin, it can also involve internal organs and cause hemolytic anemia.

diagnoses.name: Anemia of Chronic Disease
diagnoses.description: A form of anemia seen in chronic illness, including autoimmune disorders and infections. The anemia is typically moderate and arises due to the body's response to the chronic condition.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder characterized by thrombosis and pregnancy-related complications. It is also associated with hematologic abnormalities, including hemolytic anemia.

diagnoses.name: Infective Endocarditis
diagnoses.description: An infection of the heart's inner lining, usually involving the heart valves. It can cause fever, heart murmurs, petechial rashes, and has been associated with hemolytic anemia due to the destruction of blood cells.

diagnoses.name: Cryoglobulinemia
diagnoses.description: A condition associated with hepatitis C infection and certain autoimmune diseases where abnormal proteins in the blood precipitate in cooler temperatures, leading to various symptoms including skin lesions, arthritis, and kidney problems.

diagnoses.name: Cold Agglutinin Disease
diagnoses.description: A type of autoimmune hemolytic anemia caused by cold-reacting autoantibodies. Patients may experience symptoms in cold environments, including acrocyanosis, Raynaud's phenomenon, and hemolytic anemia.
